lsm_macros.h File Reference

lsm_macros.h provides some helpful macros for manipulating data arrays. More...

#include <float.h>
#include "LSMLIB_config.h"
#include "lsm_grid.h"

Detailed Description

lsm_macros.h provides some helpful macros for manipulating data arrays.

Define Documentation

#define COMPUTE_MAX_ABS_DATA (  max_abs,
data,
grid   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                          \
  int idx;                                                                 \
  LSMLIB_REAL min_err, max_err, err1, err2, err;                           \
  min_err = FLT_MAX; max_err = 0.0;                                        \
  for(idx = 0; idx < grid->num_gridpts; idx++)                             \
  {                                                                        \
    err = data[idx];                                                       \
    if(err < min_err) min_err = err;                                       \
    if(err > max_err) max_err = err;                                       \
  }                                                                        \
  err1 = fabs(min_err); err2 = fabs(max_err);                              \
  max_abs = ( err1 > err2 ) ? err1 : err2;                                 \
}
COMPUTE_MAX_ABS_DATA() computes a maximal absolute value of the data values in the array.

Arguments:

  • max_abs (out): maximal absolute value of data
  • data (in): array containing data
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid

#define COMPUTE_MAX_ABS_ERR (  max_abs_err,
data1,
data2,
grid   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                          \
  int idx;                                                                 \
  LSMLIB_REAL min_err, max_err, err1, err2, err;                           \
  min_err = FLT_MAX; max_err = 0.0;                                        \
  for(idx = 0; idx < grid->num_gridpts; idx++)                             \
  {                                                                        \
    err = data1[idx] - data2[idx];                                         \
      if(err < min_err) min_err = err;                                     \
      if(err > max_err) max_err = err;                                     \
   }                                                                       \
   err1 = fabs(min_err); err2 = fabs(max_err);                             \
   max_abs_err = ( err1 > err2 ) ? err1 : err2;                            \
}
COMPUTE_MAX_ABS_ERR() computes maximal absolute value over all points for (data1 - data2).

Arguments:

  • max_abs_err (out): maximal absolute value of (data1 - data2)
  • data1 (in): array containing data1
  • data2 (in): array containing data2
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid

#define COPY_DATA (  data_dst,
data_src,
grid   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                          \
  int idx;                                                                 \
  for(idx = 0; idx < grid->num_gridpts; idx++)                             \
  {                                                                        \
    data_dst[idx] = data_src[idx];                                         \
  }                                                                        \
}
COPY_DATA() copies values from data_src into data_dst.

Arguments:

  • data_dst (out): destination data array
  • data_src (in): source data array
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid

#define EXAMINE_ARRAY (  name,
data,
g   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                          \
  int idx;                                                                 \
  LSMLIB_REAL min = FLT_MAX, max = -FLT_MAX;                               \
  LSMLIB_REAL abs_min = FLT_MAX, abs_val;                                  \
  for(idx=0; idx < g->num_gridpts; idx++)                                  \
  {                                                                        \
    if (isnan(data[idx])) printf("\nNaN at position %d",idx);              \
    if (isinf(data[idx])) printf("\ninf at position %d",idx);              \
    if( data[idx] < min) min = data[idx];                                  \
    if( data[idx] > max) max = data[idx];                                  \
    abs_val = fabs(data[idx]);                                             \
    if( abs_val < abs_min && abs_val > DBL_EPSILON) abs_min = abs_val;     \
  }                                                                        \
  printf("\n%s min %g max %g min(|array|) %g",name,min,max,abs_min);       \
  fflush(stdout);                                                          \
}
EXAMINE_ARRAY() checks for NaN, inf values in an array and prints out min and max values for the array. Can be used for debugging purposes.

Arguments:

  • name (in): character string to be printed as array name
  • data (in): data array to be examined
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid

#define IMPOSE_MASK (  phi_masked,
mask,
phi,
grid   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                          \
  int idx;                                                                 \
  for(idx = 0; idx < grid->num_gridpts; idx++)                             \
  {                                                                        \
    phi_masked[idx] = (mask[idx] > phi[idx]) ? mask[idx] : phi[idx];       \
  }                                                                        \
}
IMPOSE_MASK() imposes constraint of the type 'phi <= mask'. That is, each point of array phi_masked is set to a maximum of the values phi and mask. This can be used for motion in restricted (but fixed) domains (i.e. the physical domain is determined by 'mask').

Arguments:

  • phi_masked (out): array with constraint 'phi<=mask' imposed
  • phi (in): array containing original values of phi
  • mask (in): array containing mask values
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid

#define IMPOSE_MASK_LOCAL (  phi_masked,
mask,
phi,
grid,
p   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                            \
   int idx, l;                                                               \
                                                                             \
   if(grid->num_dims == 3)                                                   \
     for(l = (p->n_lo)[0]; l < (p->n_hi)[0]; l++)                            \
     {                                                                       \
  idx = (p->index_x)[l] + (p->index_y)[l]*nx + (p->index_z)[l]*nxy;          \
        phi_masked[idx] = (mask[idx] > phi[idx]) ? mask[idx] : phi[idx];     \
     }                                                                       \
   else                                                                      \
     for(l = (p->n_lo)[0]; l < (p->n_hi)[0]; l++)                            \
     {                                                                       \
  idx = (p->index_x)[l] + (p->index_y)[l]*nx;                                \
        phi_masked[idx] = (mask[idx] > phi[idx]) ? mask[idx] : phi[idx];     \
     }                                                                       \
}
IMPOSE_MASK_LOCAL() imposes constraint of the type 'phi <= mask' only at local points whose coordinates are stored in index_x, index_y, index_z arrays. That is, each point of array phi_masked is set to a maximum of the values phi and mask. This can be used for motion in restricted (but fixed) domains (i.e. the physical domain is determined by 'mask').

Arguments:

  • phi_masked (out): array with constraint 'phi<=mask' imposed
  • phi (in): array containing original values of phi
  • mask (in): array containing mask values
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid

#define IMPOSE_MIN (  phi_min,
phi1,
phi2,
grid   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                        \
  int idx;                                                               \
  for(idx = 0; idx < grid->num_gridpts; idx++)                           \
  {                                                                      \
    phi_min[idx] = (phi1[idx] < phi2[idx]) ? phi1[idx] : phi2[idx];      \
  }                                                                      \
}

#define NEGATE_DATA (  data,
grid   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                          \
  int idx;                                                                 \
  for (idx = 0; idx < grid->num_gridpts; idx++)                            \
  {                                                                        \
     data[idx] = -data[idx];                                               \
  }                                                                        \
}
NEGATE_DATA() sets each data value to its negative.

Arguments:

  • data (in/out): data array of size (grid->num_gridpts)
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid

#define PRINT_ARRAY_2D (  data,
grid   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                          \
  int i,j;                                                                 \
  for(j = grid->jhi_gb; j >= grid->jlo_gb; j--)                            \
  {                                                                        \
    for(i = grid->ilo_gb; i <= grid->ihi_gb; i++)                          \
    {                                                                      \
      idx = i + j*(grid->grid_dims)[0];                                    \
      printf("%g ", data[idx]);                                            \
    }                                                                      \
    printf("\n");                                                          \
  }                                                                        \
}
PRINT_ARRAY_2D() prints a 2d array as a matrix of values. Can be used for debugging purposes.

Arguments:

  • data (in): data array
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid

#define SET_DATA_TO_CONSTANT (  data,
grid,
value   ) 
 

Value:

{                                                                          \
  int idx;                                                                 \
  for (idx = 0; idx < grid->num_gridpts; idx++)                            \
  {                                                                        \
    data[idx] = value;                                                     \
  }                                                                        \
}
SET_DATA_TO_CONSTANT() sets entire data array to a constant value.

Arguments:

  • data (out): data array of size (grid->num_gridpts)
  • grid (in): pointer to Grid
  • value (in): constant value to set data to
